content.description: A short line with a early crux requiring footwork.  Best not to have decades old rubber on this one.  Fire up with power moves and good smearing.  It eases up quickly.

Begin just right of the handcrack "

Forbidden Fruit

." Make a longish reach left to a sharp flake, then work upwards on a series of natural and chipped edges to another difficult move up high. Stick clipping the first bolt is probably a good idea.
content.protection: 5 bolts plus something for the chain anchor.

content.description: This is a nice, little, sport climb on the Forbidden Fruit Block with a low crux.  Start in from the right and quickly move into a power-favoring sequence.  Continue up with one more interesting bit near the top.
content.location: This is the 2nd route from the left of the lines.

content.description: High Test is probably the best line on the Forbidden Fruit Block and definitely worth doing. The route faces almost directly south and so is usually in the sun, it is also often open when the rest of the park is crowded.
content.protection: The protection consists of 6 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: This is currently the third route in from the left of the formation. The route begins just right of the left facing corner that is to the left of the crack which splits the entire formation. (The bolt line can actually be seen in the included photo if enlarged.) The route continues straight up the face and skirts the roof in the photo on the right hand side. The chains are just over the roof.

content.description: No ethical debates here.  A route for those who won't touch chipped rock and who just happen to have brought a rack to The Sport Park.  The eponymous and obvious crack in the middle of Forbidden Fruit Block.  Start off with a couple moves of burly fisting.  Transistion to a fingerlock, loose sticks and pebbles and copious guano.  A couple of stemming jams, a step left and you can catch your breath.  From here you can continue easily to the top or step left 4 feet to the anchors of High Test.  This is one of those pitches which on first glance invite thoughts of soloing, but once you start climbing it, you'll be glad you didn't.
content.protection: A few cams up to a #3 Camalot.  A medium nut or two is also useful.
